div.p: This content sub-element, available only within BIOGRAPHY EDUCATION , can record either the specific name or a description of an educational institution. Its attributes are REG, INSTITUTION (capturing type of school), INSTITUTIONLEVEL (from primary to post-secondary), RELIGIOUS (to identify schools teaching a particular faith), and STUDENTBODY (with attributes CO-ED and SINGLESEX). Encloses name of institution (Ilminster Grammar School; St Anne’s College,, Oxford University) or description if no name is available (a convent school, a short-lived typing school). Should be used in combination with ORGNAME for institutions prominent enough to be potentially named elsewhere in the system, but not for those unlikely ever to be mentioned again (Miss Brodie’s Academy for Young Ladies).

Attribute REG on SCHOOL allows you to express the name of the school in a standard form if you have been unable to do in your prose, and is useful for long-established schools that have changed their names. Colleges at collegiate universities take college name, double comma, university name (Trinity College,, University of Toronto). A few ancient universities named for places take the form without of: Oxford University.

div.codeblock: VW received her BA from Cambridge University. WP's early education included governesses and dayschools. She also attended Wycombe Abbey School and St Leonard's School.

div.p: In the above example, the name of the dayschool is not known but it should be tagged with the appropriate attributes. Wycombe Abbey and St Leonard's are well-known girls’ schools. The Orlando textbase supplies details on the first, but reveals that the second was a name borne by several schools, which therefore needs its location given if possible as well as attributes supplied.

All identifiable insitutions ALSO require an ORGNAME tag. You will not need to use ORGNAME when referring to a dayschool with no known proper name. All universities should be given an attribute for INSTITUTIONLEVEL with post-secondary marked off. If all you know is what kind of school she attended (for example, boarding school) but not the name of the specific institution, include it in a school tag with the appropriate attributes marked. Try to ensure all appropriate attributes are filled in, using the tagger’s best judgement if evidence is thin. (n.b. Oxbridge colleges that had years as SINGLESEX) (male) are now CO-ED.)
